Name: Subsistence economy: gathering
Description: Dependence on the gathering of wild plants and small land fauna, relative to other subsistence activities.

Name: Subsistence economy: hunting
Description: Dependence on hunting, including trapping and fowling, relative to other subsistence activities.

Name: Subsistence economy: fishing
Description: Dependence on fishing, including shellfishing and the pursuit of large aquatic animals, relative to other subsistence activities.

Name: Subsistence economy: animal husbandry
Description: Dependence on animal husbandry, relative to other subsistence activities.

Name: Subsistence economy: agriculture
Description: Dependence on agriculture, relative to other subsistence activities.

Name: Transactions at marriage: prevailing type
Description: Prevailing type of transfer or exchange at marriage.

Name: Transactions at marriage: alternate type
Description: Alternative types of transfer or exchange at marriage, or supplementary practices.

Name: Domestic organization
Description: The prevailing form of domestic or familial organization.

Name: Marital composition: monogamy and polygamy
Description: Marital composition of family units, regardless of whether families live as independent nuclear units or as part of larger extended families.

Name: Marital residence with kin: first years
Description: Pattern of marital residence in the first years or so of marriage. The variable "Marital residence with kin: change after first years" indicates whether or not this differs from the pattern of marital residence in later years.
Changes: Recoded to be a "stand alone" variable. Now, societies for which code was "not different than later years" have this information spelled out, using detailed codes of Gray's v12, which describes the pattern of marital residence in later years. Note also that two codes were added for "Uv" and "Vu" based on Murdock's note under the Ambilocal code. Specifically: "The symbols Uv or Vu are used to denote, respectively, a marked preponderance of uxorilocal or virilocal practice [in ambilocal residence]. That is, cases of ambilocal residence where the actual frequency of uxorilocal vs. virilocal residence exceeds the other by a ratio greater than two to one.
Notes: Codes for "first years" in Murdock do not include options for Matrilocal/Patrilocalï¾…it is not clear if these are contained in Uxorilocal/Virilocal. In the case of the "Marital residence (prevailing pattern)" variable Matrilocal/Patrilocal are distinguished by Uxorilocal/Virilocal (with the latter being "confined to instances where the wife's [husband's] matrikin [patrikin] are not aggregated in matrilocal and matrilineal [patrilocal and matrilineal] kin groups". If comparing with v10 with v12, users may wish to look into this further and/or group Matri/Uxori and Patri/Viri in v12.

Name: Marital residence with kin: change after first years
Description: Indicates whether or not the pattern of marital residence differs in the first years of marriage relative to later years.
Changes: Added because of the recoding of v10, to allow users to quickly identify societies where marital residence in early years differs from that in later years.

Name: Transfer of residence at marriage: prevailing pattern
Description: The prevailing pattern of transfer of residence at marriage (note: not in original EA, summarized from variable describing marital residence with kin).
Changes: Revised codes for avunculocal cases, as these should be "Wife to husband's group"; changed wording of this code (code "1") to emphasize that this group could be husband's group (patrilocal, virilocal) or husband's mother's brother's household (avunculocal).
Notes: Note that in cases where men marry a MoBrDa, 'avunculocal' residence would mean the husband was moving to the wife's household.

Name: Marital residence with kin: prevailing pattern
Description: The prevailing profile of marital residence in the society.
Changes: Two codes added for "Uv" and "Vu" based on Murdock's note under the Ambilocal code. Specifically: "The symbols Uv or Vu are used to denote, respectively, a marked preponderance of uxorilocal or virilocal practice [in ambilocal residence]". He further specifies that these are cases of ambilocal residence where the actual frequency of uxorilocal vs. virilocal residence exceeds the other by a ratio greater than two to one. Given this specific definition, we decided these two cases should be "stand alone" codes under v12, rather than cases where a prevailing pattern (v12) is accompanied by an alternative pattern (v14).

Name: Transfer of residence at marriage: alternate
Description: Culturally patterned alternatives to, or numerically significant deviations from, the prevailing pattern of transfer of residence at marriage (note: not in original EA, summarized from variable describing marital residence with kin).
Changes: Revised codes for avunculocal cases here and for variable EA011, as these should be "Wife to husband's group"; changed wording of this code (code "1") to emphasize that this group could be husband's group (patrilocal, virilocal) or husband's mother's brother's household (avunculocal). Because codes for this variable are dependent on EA011, adjusted all codes for this variable after adjusting EA011 and this variable for avunculocal cases.
Notes: Note that in cases where men marry a MoBrDa, 'avunculocal' residence would mean the husband was moving to the wife's household.

Name: Marital residence with kin: alternate
Description: Culturally patterned alternatives to, or numerically significant deviations from, the prevailing profile of marital residence.
Changes: No change, despite change to v12, for wich "Uv" and "Vu" now coded as specific cases. In other words, ".v" following U and ".u" following V are still coded as 'alternative states' to v12.

Name: Community marriage organization
Description: The prevalence of local endogamy, agamy, and exogamy, together with the presence or absence of localized kin groups. The specific structure of clans, whether ambilocal, matrilocal, or patrilocal, is revealed by the variable describing prevailing patterns of residence with kin.

Name: Organization of clan communities
Description: Indicates whether or not societies organized as clan-communities (i.e., where communities represent a single, localized, exogamous kin group or clan) are also segmented into clan barrios.

Name: Largest patrilineal kin group
Description: The largest type of patrilineal kin group reported for the society.

Name: Largest patrilineal exogamous group
Description: The largest patrilineal kin group characterized by exogamy.
Changes: Recoded to be a "stand alone" variable. Any societies coded as "9" ("No different from variable 17") in Gray (1999) are now represented by their codes in v17. Also, "O," "Lo," "Po," and "So" are here coded as "1" ("No patrilineal exogamy"). In Gray (1999), O, Lo, So, Po were coded as "9" ("No different from variable 17").

Name: Largest matrilineal kin group
Description: The largest type of matrilineal kin group reported for the society.

Name: Largest matrilineal exogamous group
Description: The largest matrilineal kin group characterized by exogamy.
Changes: Recoded to be a "stand alone" variable. Any societies coded as "9" ("No different from variable 19") in Gray (1999) are now represented by their codes in v19. Also, "O," "Lo," "Po," and "So" are here coded as "1" ("No matrilineal exogamy"). In Gray (1999), O, Lo, So, Po were coded as "9" ("No different from variable 17").

Name: Cognatic kin groups
Description: The presence or probable absence, and the typology, of cognatic kin groups.

Name: Secondary cognatic kin group: kindreds and ramages
Description: The presence or probable absence, and the typology, of secondary cognatic kin groups. This variable highlights societies for which both kindreds (bilateral descent) and ramages (ambilineal descent) are reported.

Name: Cousin marriages permitted
Description: The rules or practices governing the marriageability or nonmarriageability of a man's first cousins and, in some cases, second cousins.

Name: Cousin marriages permitted: subtypes
Description: Number of types of cousins (first and/or second cousins) a man is permitted to marry.
Changes: Used code that was corrected by Gray after publication of Gray (1999). Specifically, Murdock codes "C-G" = Gray code "3" and only Murdock codes "M" and "P" = Gray code "4"

Name: Cousin marriages preferred
Description: Preferred rather than just permitted marriages to particular first (and/or second) cousins.

Name: Cousin marriages preferred: subtypes
Description: Specific type(s) of cousin preferred as spouses.

Name: Kin terms for cousins
Description: Extent to which names for cousins distinguish cousin subtypes and/or among other groups of kin.

Name: Agriculture: intensity
Description: Intensity of cultivation.

Name: Agriculture: major crop type
Description: Principal type of crop cultivated.
Changes: Societies coded as "C" but without a lower-case letter following are here coded as "0" (i.e., as having Missing data for "Principal crop").

Name: Settlement patterns
Description: The prevailing type of settlement pattern.

Name: Mean size of local communities
Description: The average population of local communities, whatever the pattern of settlement, computed from census data or other evidence.

Name: Jurisdictional hierarchy of local community
Description: The number of jurisdictional levels in the local community, with 2 representing the theoretical minimum (e.g., independent nuclear or polygynous families) and 4 representing the theoretical maximum (e.g., nuclear families nested within extended families and clan-barrios). See the variable "Jurisdictional hierarchy beyond the local community" for information on organization beyond the local community. Note that different types of organization on the same level, e.g., a consanguineal lineage and its localized equivalent, are counted as one, and organizations not held to be legitimate, e.g., imposed colonial regimes, are excluded.

Name: Jurisdictional hierarchy beyond local community
Description: The number of jurisdictional levels beyond the local community, with 1 representing the theoretical minimum (e.g.,  none/autonomous bands or villages) and 4 representing the theoretical maximum (e.g., villages nested within parishes, districts, provinces, and a complex state). This variable also provides a measure of political complexity, ranging from 1 for stateless societies, through 2 or 3 for petty and larger paramount chiefdoms or their equivalent, to 4 or 5 for large states. Note that different types of organization on the same level are counted as one, and organizations not held to be legitimate, e.g., imposed colonial regimes, are excluded.

Name: Religion: high gods
Description: The range of beliefs in high gods. A high god is defined, following Swanson, as a spiritual being who is believed to have created all reality and/or to be its ultimate governor, even if his sole act was to create other spirits who, in turn, created or control the natural world.

Name: Games
Description: Types of games practiced. Following Roberts, only games with an outcome, i.e., a winner and a loser, are treated.

Name: Post-partum sex taboos
Description: The normal duration of post-partum sex taboos, i.e., those requiring a lactating mother to refrain from sexual intercourse.

Name: Male genital mutilations
Description: The practice of circumcision or any of its variants, when culturally normative and not sporadic or merely optional, as well as the age at which it typically occurs.

Name: Segregation of adolescent boys
Description: Degree and mode of segregating boys at or approaching puberty.

Name: Domestic animals: plow cultivation
Description: Indicates whether or not animals are employed in plow cultivation, and whether plow cultivation is aboriginal or dates to the post-contact period.

Name: Domestic animals: type
Description: The predominant type of animals kept.

Name: Domestic animals: milking
Description: Indicates whether or not domestic animals milked.

Name: Subsistence economy: dominant activity
Description: Dominant mode of subsistence (note: not in original EA; derived from other variables on subsistence and type of agriculture).

Name: Descent: major type
Description: Major mode of descent (note: not in original EA; derived from variables describing patrilineal and matrilineal kin groups EA017, EA019 and EA021).

Name: Sex differences: metal working
Description: Specialization by sex in such arts as smelting, casting, and forging, i.e., only those which involve the application of fire.

Name: Sex differences: weaving
Description: Specialization by sex in the manufacture of true cloth on a loom or frame; not including the manufacture of nets, baskets, mats, or nonwoven fabrics like barkcloth or felt.

Name: Sex differences: leather working
Description: Specialization by sex in the dressing of skins, e.g., by tanning; not including the manufacture of artifacts from raw hides or undressed skins.

Name: Sex differences: pottery making
Description: Specialization by sex in the manufacture of earthenware utensils.

Name: Sex differences: boat building
Description: Specialization by sex in the construction of true water craft; not including the making of simple floats, rafts, or the like.

Name: Sex differences: house construction
Description: Specialization by sex in the actual building of a permanent dwelling or the erection of a transportable shelter; not including the acquisition or preliminary preparation of the materials used.

Name: Sex differences: gathering
Description: Specialization by sex in the gathering of wild plants and small land fauna.

Name: Sex differences: hunting
Description: Specialization by sex in hunting, including trapping and fowling.

Name: Sex Differences: fishing
Description: Specialization by sex in fishing, including shellfishing and the pursuit of large aquatic animals.

Name: Sex differences: animal husbandry
Description: Specialization by sex in animal husbandry.

Name: Sex differences: agriculture
Description: Specialization by sex in agriculture.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: metal working
Description: Age or occupational specialization in such arts as smelting, casting, and forging, i.e., only those which involve the application of fire.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: weaving
Description: Age or occupational specialization in the manufacture of true cloth on a loom or frame; not including the manufacture of nets, baskets, mats, or nonwoven fabrics like barkcloth or felt.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: leather working
Description: Age or occupational specialization in the dressing of skins, e.g., by tanning; not including the manufacture of artifacts from raw hides or undressed skins.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: pottery making
Description: Age or occupational specialization in the manufacture of earthenware utensils.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: boat building
Description: Age or occupational specialization in the construction of true water craft; not including the making of simple floats, rafts, or the like.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: house construction
Description: Age or occupational specialization in the actual building of a permanent dwelling or the erection of a transportable shelter; not including the acquisition or preliminary preparation of the materials used.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: gathering
Description: Age or occupational specialization in the gathering of wild plants and small land fauna.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: hunting
Description: Age or occupational specialization in hunting, including trapping and fowling.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: fishing
Description: Age or occupational specialization in fishing, including shellfishing and the pursuit of large aquatic animals.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: animal husbandry
Description: Age or occupational specialization in animal husbandry.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Age or occupational specialization: agriculture
Description: Age or occupational specialization in agriculture.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where activity is not practiced from cases where there is no specialization by sex.

Name: Class differentiation: primary
Description: The degree and type of class differentiation, excluding purely political and religious statuses. See also "Class differentiation: secondary," as some societies exhibit important features of two different types of class differentation.

Name: Class differentiation: secondary features
Description: Secondary type of class differentiation present in the society, excluding purely political and religious statuses. See also "Class differentiation: primary".

Name: Caste differentiation: primary
Description: The degree and type of caste differentiation. See also "Caste differentiation: secondary," as some societies exhibit important features of two different types of caste differentation.

Name: Caste differentiation: secondary features
Description: Secondary type of caste differentiation. See also "Caste differentiation: primary".

Name: Slavery: type
Description: The forms and prevalence of slave status, treated quite independently of both class and caste status.

Name: Slavery: timing
Description: Indicates whether slavery present at the time of observation of the society, or only in the past.
Changes: Recoded to be a "standalone" variable; specifically, to distinguish "Slavery never practiced" (1) from "Slavery present in past, but not currently in existence" (3)

Name: Political succession
Description: Rules of succession applying to the office of local headman (or a close equivalent), without reference to rules of succession prevailing on higher levels of political integration.
Changes: Note: recoded from Murdock and split into two variables by Gray (1999)

Name: Political succession: hereditary succession
Description: Rules of succession applying to the office of local headman (or a close equivalent), without reference to rules of succession prevailing on higher levels of political integration.

Name: Inheritance rule for real property (land)
Description: The rule or practice governing the disposition or transmission of a man's property in land (exclusive of any dower right of his widow). [Note that Murdock (1963a) warned that the codes for this variable had "proved inadequate and in serious need of revision," and that the coded data "should consequently be used only with circumspection"].

Name: Inheritance distribution for real property (land)
Description: Following the inheritance rule for real property (land), this variable indicates how real property is distributed among several individuals of the same category. [Note that Murdock (1963a) warned that the codes for this variable had "proved inadequate and in serious need of revision," and that the coded data "should consequently be used only with circumspection"].

Name: Inheritance rule for movable property
Description: The rule or practice governing the disposition or transmission of a man's movable property (exclusive of any dower right of his widow). [Note that Murdock (1963a) warned that the codes for this variable had "proved inadequate and in serious need of revision," and that the coded data "should consequently be used only with circumspection"].

Name: Inheritance distribution for movable property
Description: Following the inheritance rule for movable property, this variable indicates how movable property is distributed among several individuals of the same category. [Note that Murdock (1963a) warned that the codes for this variable had "proved inadequate and in serious need of revision," and that the coded data "should consequently be used only with circumspection"].
Changes: Recoded to distinguish cases where no inheritance of movable property ("9") from cases where no data provided on distribution rules (Missing data).

Name: Norms of premarital sexual behavior of girls
Description: Prevailing standards of sex behavior for unmarried women.

Name: House construction: ground plan
Description: Ground plan of the prevailing type of dwelling.

Name: House construction: floor level
Description: Floor level of the prevailing type of dwelling.

Name: House construction: wall material
Description: Wall material of the prevailing type of dwelling.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish "missing data" (0) from "open walls" (10) from "walls indistinguishable from, or merging into roof" (11)

Name: House construction: shape of roof
Description: Shape of roof  of the prevailing type of dwelling.

Name: House construction: roofing materials
Description: Roofing materials of the prevailing type of dwelling.

Name: House construction (secondary house type): ground plan
Description: Ground plan of secondary or alternative house type.

Name: House construction (secondary house type): floor level
Description: Floor level of secondary or alternative house type.

Name: House construction (secondary house type): wall material
Description: Wall material of secondary or alternative house type.
Changes: Recoded to distinguish "missing data" (0) from "open walls" (10) from "walls indistinguishable from, or merging into roof" (11)

Name: House construction (secondary house type): shape of roof
Description: Shape of roof of secondary or alternative house type.

Name: House construction (secondary house type): roofing materials
Description: Roofing materials of secondary or alternative house type.

Name: Political integration
Description: Political integration of the society with neighbouring communities and/or a larger state; this is the version that appeared in Murdock (1957)'s World Ethnographic Sample (WES).

Name: Political succession: version from Murdock (1957)
Description: Rule of succession; for cross-cultural comparibility this is the prevailing rule of succession for the headman of a local community or a near equivalent thereto; this is the version that appeared in Murdock (1957)'s World Ethnographic Sample (WES).

Name: Trance states
Description: Presence/absence of culturally patterned forms of altered states of consciousness. Codes distinguish between two types of altered states: PossessionTrance, considered to be a manifestation of spirit possession, and a Trance state that is not explained by possession.

Name: Societal rigidity
Description: Degree of rigidity in social structures. Considers stratification of society, whether status distinctions are earned or ascribed, degree of hierarchy of political system, extent to which residence and group membership are fixed, centralization of authority, flexibility of religious rites.

Name: Population size
Description: Population of ethnic group as a whole, unless otherwise noted in "Comments". Note that source differs by society; EA bibliography is source where possible, otherwise Ember (1992).

Name: Subsistence economy: Gathering
Description: Group's dependence upon gathering of terrestrial plants, relative to other subsistence activities.
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Subsistence economy: Hunting
Description: Group's dependence upon hunting of terrestrial animals, relative to other subsistence activities
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Subsistence economy: Fishing
Description: Group's dependence upon fishing of aquatic organisms, relative to other subsistence activities
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Subsistence economy: Most important activity
Description: Subsistence activity that provides the majority of a group's nutritional intake (hunting, gathering, or fishing)
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) pp. 117, 312

Name: Subsistence economy: Deviation from HGF at documentation
Description: Character of a group's subsistence economy at the time of documentation (i.e., was susbsistence truly through hunting, gathering, fishing, only?). Groups are coded as either "normal" or "suspect".
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 244

Name: Population of ethnic group
Description: Total number of persons to whom the the ethnographic description applies
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Area occupied by ethnic group (square km)
Description: Ethnographers' estimates of the total land area occupied by the group, in square kilometers
Changes: Binford provided estimates in units of '100 square km,' rather than 'square km'
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Population density (persons per square km)
Description: Population of ethnic group divided by area occupied by ethnic group (persons per square km)
Changes: Binford provided estimates in 'person per 100 square km' rather than in 'persons per square km'
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Mobility of group
Description: Is the population mobile or sedentary?
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Size of smallest group that regularly cooperates for subsistence
Description: Mean size of the mobile consumer unit that camps together during the most dispersed phase of the settlement cycle. For sedentary groups, the entry indicates the size of the mobile task group operating out of a relatively permanent settlement, as in the case of family units moving together in a ‘walkabout’ strategy during some season of the year. (Binford's "GRP1").
Source: Binford (2001) Tables 5.01 and 8.01; variable 'GROUP1' (Table 5.01) or 'MOST DISPERSED' (Table 8.01)
Changes: In cases where tables 5.01 and 8.01 provided different values for the same society, we adopted the value from table 8.01 because data points in that table were tagged with their specific reference (including page numbers). These cases are flagged by a comment in the "Comments" field.
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) pp. 117, 143, 236, 244

Name: Size of village or camp when population most aggregated
Description: Mean size of the consumer group that regularly camps together during the most aggregated phase of the yearly economic cycles (applies to groups that are mobile, moving entire population from camp to camp as subsistence activities are carried out). For sedentary groups, this is village size.  (Binford's "GRP2").
Source: Binford (2001) Tables 5.01 and 8.01; variable 'GROUP2' (Table 5.01) or 'MOST AGGREGATED' (Table 8.01)
Changes: In cases where tables 5.01 and 8.01 provided different values for the same society, we adopted the value from table 8.01 because data points in that table were tagged with their specific reference (including page numbers). These cases are flagged by a comment in the "Comments" field.
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) pp. 117, 144, 237, 244

Name: Size of periodic regional aggregations
Description: Mean size of multigroup encampments that may aggregate periodically, but not necessarily annually, for immediate subsistence-related activities. (Binford's "GRP3").
Source: Binford (2001) Tables 5.01 and 8.01; variable 'GROUP3' (Table 5.01) or 'PERIODIC REGIONAL AGGREGATIONS' (Table 8.01)
Changes: In cases where tables 5.01 and 8.01 provided different values for the same society, we adopted the value from table 8.01 because data points in that table were tagged with their specific reference (including page numbers). These cases are flagged by a comment in the "Comments" field.
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) pp. 117, 145, 244

Name: Number of moves per year
Description: Number of moves per year, with 0 moves indicating that society is sedentary
Source: Binford (2001) Tables 5.01 and 8.04.; variable 'NOMOV' (Table 5.01) or 'NUMBER OF MOVES PER YEAR' (Table 8.01)
Changes: In cases where tables 5.01 and 8.04 provided different values for the same society, we adopted the value from table 8.04 because data points in that table were tagged with their specific reference (including page numbers). These cases are flagged by a comment in the "Comments" field.
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 117

Name: Distance moved per year (km)
Description: Total distance moved between camps/settlements in a year. A distance of 0 indicates society is sedentary.
Source: Binford (2001) Tables 5.01 and 8.04.; variable 'DISMOV' (Table 5.01) or 'DISTANCE MOVED PER YEAR' (Table 8.01)
Changes: In cases where tables 5.01 and 8.04 provided different values for the same society, we adopted the value from table 8.04 because data points in that table were tagged with their specific reference (including page numbers). These cases are flagged by a comment in the "Comments" field. Note that Binford's table 8.04 provides estimates in miles rather than in km.
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) pp. 117, 150

Name: Household size
Description: Number of persons residing in a single structure

Name: Family size
Description: Number of persons per family

Name: Domestic organization
Description: The prevailing form of domestic or familial organization
Source: Binford (2001) Table 8.08; variable 'HOUSEHOLD TYPE' (converted to numeric codes following Gray (1999))

Name: Marital composition: monogamy and polygamy
Description: Marital composition of family units, regardless of whether families live as independent nuclear units or as part of larger extended families
Source: Binford (2001) Table 8.08; variable 'HOUSEHOLD TYPE' (converted to numeric codes following Gray (1999))

Name: Polygyny
Description: Percentage of males with more than one wife

Name: Age of males at first marriage
Description: Mean age (in years) of males at first marriage
Source: Binford (2001) Table 8.07; variable 'AGE AT MARRIAGE - MALE'

Name: Age of females at first marriage
Description: Mean age (in years) of females at first marriage
Source: Binford (2001) Table 8.07; variable 'AGE AT MARRIAGE - FEMALE'

Name: Mean household size (in small subsistence groups)
Description: An estimate of mean household size based on the following calculation: number of persons in smallest group that regularly cooperates for subsistence, divided by number of households in one of these groups
Notes: Code and variable definitions from Binford and Johnson (2006)

Name: Mean family size (in small subsistence groups)
Description: An estimate of mean family size based on the following calculation: number of persons in smallest group that regularly cooperates for subsistence, divided by number of married men in group
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p.286 and Binford and Johnson (2006)

Name: Mean household size (in villages or large camps)
Description: An estimate of mean household size based on the following calculation: number of persons per settlement (i.e., village or camp at time of year when population is most aggregated), divided by number of households per settlement

Name: Mean family size (in villages or large camps)
Description: Mean family size calculated as: number of persons per settlement (i.e., village or camp at time of year when population is most aggregated), divided by number of married men per settlement.

Name: Number of families per household
Description: Mean number of families per household

Name: Jurisdictional hierarchy of local community
Description: Political complexity at level of local community
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 244, caption to fig. 8.02; p.338, caption to Fig 9.06

Name: Political relationship to neighbouring groups
Description: Political and economic position of the group relative to other groups in the region
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 404

Name: Type of social class distinction
Description: Type of social class distinction
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 396

Name: Perogatives of leadership
Description: Perogatives of leadership, regardless of the types of leadership present in the group
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p.338, caption to Fig 9.06

Name: Use of money
Description: Presence or absence of use of money within the society
Notes: Code and variable definitions from Binford and Johnson (2006)

Name: Economic specialization
Description: Whether there is economic role specialization beyond simple age and gender differences
Notes: More detail on variable in Binford (2001) p. 333, but no code definitions; division of labor discussed briefly on p. 244; code definitions from Binford and Johnson (2006)

Name: Community marriage organization
Description: The prevalence of local endogamy, agamy, and exogamy coded together with the presence or absence of localized kin groups. Can be interpreted as ordinal measure of endogamy.
Notes: Code and variable definitions from Binford and Johnson (2006)

Name: Community facilities
Description: The functions and properties of structures with specific community-wide functions. These are not residences, nor are they multifunctional residences.
Notes: Code and variable definitions from Binford and Johnson (2006)

Name: Ownership of resource locations
Description: Ownership of resource locations
Notes: Code definitions somewhat ambiguous, see Binford (2001) p. 426, caption to Fig. 11.17

Name: System state: typology of society's political organization
Description: Variable represents a combination of data relating to leadership, internal differentiation of leadership status, associated roles relative to participation in decision making, and the exercise of power within the society. According to Binford (2001) these include some of the criteria used in "more thoughtful evolutionary classifications," such as ones by Fried (1967) and Jonson and Earle (1987).
Notes: More detail on code definitions and variable in Binford (2001) p. 345; Codes given in caption for figure 9.02.

Name: Height (male, mm)
Description: Stature (mm) - Male
Source: Binford (2001) Table 6.03; variable 'STATURE (CM*) - MALE' (*should be mm)

Name: Height (female, mm)

Name: Sleeping Proximity of Parents to Infant
Description:
Variables 23-32 deal with infancy only, from the first year until the transition to early childhood (see 38-39, 42, 44), usually at 12-18 months.The early and late infancy periods of variables 24-27 refer to the first few months after birth versus the period after crawling begins,usually around 9 months. Variables 33-38 include both infancy and early childhood, the latter usually to the age of 4-5 years. Variables 39-50 deal with the transition to childhood, around 12-18 months.Variables 51-60 provide a comparison of infancy and childhood.

Name: Importance of Trade in Subsistence
Description:
Include trade conducted to gain needed subsistence items, not simply exchange of ceremonial items; measure of extent to which members of the community depend upon trading in order to acquire items needed for subsistence that they do not produce themselves (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Sexual Expression in Adolescent Boys
Description:
Encouragement of sexual behavior, taking into account its frequency, emotional intensity, importance, and variety (including range of partners) in adolescence. Heterosexual intercourse is the principal criterion, but heterosexual foreplay, masturbation, homosexuality, sexual jokes, and exposing the genitals were also considered.

Barry, H., & Schlegel, A. (1984). Measurements of adolescent sexual behavior in the standard sample of societies. Ethnology, 23(4), 315-329.

Name: Sexual Expression in Adolescent Girls
Description: Barry, H., & Schlegel, A. (1984). Measurements of adolescent sexual behavior in the standard sample of societies. Ethnology, 23(4), 315-329.

Name: Sexual Nonrestraint in Adolescent Boys
Description:
The absence of sexual restraints such as taboos or restrictions on heterosexual intercourse and other erotic behavior, including heterosexual play, masturbation, and homosexuality. A high degree of modesty, such as the requirement to keep the genitals constantly covered in public, indicates moderate restraint. Incest taboos, if highly emphasized or widely extended, are considered as indicators of restraint. Note: Sexual nonrestraint = Sexual expression + 1 more or less. The authors indicate the advisability of using the sum of the two scores as a Sexual Freedom index.

Barry, H., & Schlegel, A. (1984). Measurements of adolescent sexual behavior in the standard sample of societies. Ethnology, 23(4), 315-329.

Barry, H., & Schlegel, A. (1984). Measurements of adolescent sexual behavior in the standard sample of societies. Ethnology, 23(4), 315-329.

Name: Frequency of Internal War Otterbein (1970: 3, 84, 143) Definition of Internal War
Description:
Otterbein's (1970: 3, 84, 143) definition of internal war excludes feuding: warfare between political communities within the cultural unit, i.e., continguous political communities that are culturally similar. p. 3: Warfare is defined as armed combat between political communities. Armed combat, which is fighting with weapons, is performed by military organizations. When political communities within the same cultural unit engage in warfare, this is considered to be internal war. p. 143: If there is more than one military organization within a political community, and these ... engage in armed combat, this is considered feuding or civil war, depending on the scope of the conflict. (note source: DRW codebook)

Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: DW NOTE: (Var Label Reversed). Another note in DW codebook says: References cited: Naroll, Raoul. 1966. Does military deterrence deter? Trans-Action 3(2): 14-20. and Otterbein, Keith F. 1970. The Evolution of War: A Cross-cultural study. HRAF Press.

Notes: (Var Label Reversed) This has turned out to be a difficult variable to code; information does not exist in most cases. Wheeler l974:270 (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Leadership during Battle [modified from Otterbein 1970: 23-28, 144]
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: When I drew up this variable, I neglected to allow for those cases where a leader has an official position -- appointed war chief, hereditary war chief -- and is very aware of the honor and respect of this office but still has no means to force followers to obey. His formality may be hollow if people choose to disregard his direction. Wheeler l974:272 (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Prestige Associated with Being a Soldier or Warrior
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: (Var Label Reversed) (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Cowardice: Defined As
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: This variable is a failure, but for an interesting reason. With very few exceptions, even including professionally trained ethnographers, observers simply do not state what action brings down an accusation of cowardice. Cowardice is often mentioned, but not what it is seen to be. Wheeler 1974: 273. (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Rewards (Special Gifts, Praises, or Ceremonies, Not including Ritual Purification for a Man Who Has Killed an Enemy in Battle or Otherwise Shown Skill in War)
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: (Var Label Reversed) This variable augments variable [903] Wheeler l974:273 (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Did Members of the Society Expect Violence to Solve Their Problems?
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: (Var Label Reversed) My operationalization of this variable breaks all the methodological rules and consequently is vulnerable to attack... the coder has used his assessment of the material overall.... I think the variable is enormously important, and eventually I hope to build some rigor ... into it. Wheeler l974:274-5. (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Value of War: Violence/War against Non-members of the Group
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: (Var Label Reversed) This variable complements but does not duplicate, or resolve, variable [906].... Clumsy as this variable may seem, it was quite easy to code, largely due to clear observation by the ethnographer as to the value of war. The evidence may be comments by the observer, texts or poems and songs, or statements by the actors. Wheeler l974: 275 (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Military Success : Is Political Community/Cultural Unit Winning or Losing in the Long Run

Notes: (Var Label Reversed) (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Revenge
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: (Var Label Reversed) (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Defense
Description: Nammour, V. W. (1974). Drums And Guns: A Cross-cultural Study Of The Nature Of War. (Doctoral Dissertation, University of Oregon).
Notes: (Var Label Reversed) The coding of defense was generally difficult because so few authors specifically mentioned it. Following the rule [of coding no mentions as absences], I marked it as absent, I simply do not know where it was truly absent and where the ethnographer assumed that any ninny would know that it [must] exist. Otterbein (1970) also had difficulty coding this attribute because of such an assumption. Therefore, I do not consider my quantitative results on defense to be reliable. Otterbein made one useful distinction that I could not implement satisfactorily. He coded the military expectations in order of importance -- first, second, third. There were too many cases where I could not make such a judgment, even if the data on expectations per se were good. Wheeler l974:270. (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Aggressive Defense (Pre-emptive Attack If Enemy Thought about to Attack)

Notes: (Var Label Reversed) (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Historical Frame for Pinpointing Date Where Slaveholding Present
Description:
Patterson defines slaveholding as permanent dominant violation of natally alienated and generally dishonored persons. This excludes non-hereditary slavery, and thus does not include what Murdock (1967: 166) classifies as incipient slavery. His focus is on slaveholding societies, and excludes societies largely composed of former slaves.

Patterson, O. (1982). Slavery and social death. Harvard University Press.

Description: Frayser, S. G. (1985). Varieties of sexual experience: An anthropological perspective on human sexuality. Human Relations Area Files.

Name: Type of Birth Celebration
Description:
Celebration of birth: The degree of social concern with the birth of a child as indicated by the amount of celebration after the birth and the extent of social participation in it. The codes apply to the largest social class and exclude such particular occasions as the celebratino of multiple births or the birth of an heir to a king. Coded for the first born if there is a difference in treatment for different births. Coded for the desired sex if there is a difference for males and females

Frayser, S. G. (1985). Varieties of sexual experience: An anthropological perspective on human sexuality. Human Relations Area Files.

Name: When the Birth Celebration Occurs
Description: Frayser, S. G. (1985). Varieties of sexual experience: An anthropological perspective on human sexuality. Human Relations Area Files.

Name: Participants in the Birth Celebration. the Code Indicates the Most Extensive Group Which Participates in the Celebration of Birth
Description: Frayser, S. G. (1985). Varieties of sexual experience: An anthropological perspective on human sexuality. Human Relations Area Files.
Notes: Ranked According to the Extensiveness of the Group (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Warfare Mortality (E&e 1983: 118)
Description: White, D. R., & Burton, M. L. (1988). Causes of polygyny: Ecology, economy, kinship, and warfare. American Anthropologist, 90(4), 871-887.
Notes: From "STDS53.COD" in WC 5#4:  "Included here are some of the variety of codes used by Douglas White and Michael Burton (American Anthropologist 1988) as background variables in testing theories (including the role of warfare) about polygyny. Tests of "Alternative Warfare Explanations" (p. 881) included the use of a warfare mortality code by Ember and Ember (1983), and led to a compilation of internal and external warfare ratings by Keith Otterbein and Carol and Melvin Ember for societies in their samples that overlapped with the standard sample.  Annotations for locating the Embers' (and Otterbein's) codes are given in coding notes (STDS53.ANO).  White supplemented the codes on these variables by rating some of these same societies plus many others not rated by these other authors.  Reliabilities of the Ember's ratings were found to be high.  Sources for societies newly coded by White are listed in notes following the coded data."

Name: Despotic Bias in Conflict Resolution
Description:

It Does Not Include Such Asymmetry over Slaves Nor over Members of the Household. (note source: DRW codebook)

Betzig, L. L. (1986). Despotism and differential reproduction: A Darwinian view of history. Aldine Publishing Co.

Name: Jurisdictional Perquisites
Description:
A Measure of the Extent to Which Individuals in the Jurisdictional Hierarchy Exploit Their Positions to Accrue Rewards in the Form of Fines, Bribes, and Confiscations, in Connection with Dispute Resolution. (note source: DRW codebook)

Notes: The original code contained values 1 through 5 and was used in a number of published studies (Ember and Ember 1992b; Ember et al. 1992; Ember and Ember 1994). The code was subsequently revised to values between 1 and 17 by Carol Ember, Melvin Ember, and J. Patrick Gray (Carol Ember, personal communication to Anthon Eff). (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Outcomes regarding Land in External Warfare
Description: Ember, C. R., & Ember, M. (1992). Warfare, aggression, and resource problems: Cross-cultural codes. Behavior Science Research, 26(1-4), 169-226.
Notes: Note, codes not ordered (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Outcomes regarding Land in War Overall - Combined Scale Scores from Vars 1655 and 1656
Description: Ember, C. R., & Ember, M. (1992). Warfare, aggression, and resource problems: Cross-cultural codes. Behavior Science Research, 26(1-4), 169-226.
Notes: If both internal and external warfare were present, and if the coders made a resolved rating for both types of outcomes, we used the higher scale score of Vars 1655 or 1656 for the rating of Var 1657. If there was only one resolved rating (between 1 and 5 on the original scale) and the other rating was 8 ( don't know ), we used the former, but only if that score was in the high categories (3-5); if the former scale was in the low categories (1-2), the case was listed as uncodable in Var 1657. If there was only 1 resolved rating between 1 and 5, and if the other rating was 9 ( not applicable ), we used the former for Var 1657. If the case could not be coded for the above rules, or if the scores for internal and external warfare were 8 or 9, the case was scored as 0. (Codes Not Ordered) (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Outcomes regarding Nonland Resources in Internal Warfare
Description: Ember, C. R., & Ember, M. (1992). Warfare, aggression, and resource problems: Cross-cultural codes. Behavior Science Research, 26(1-4), 169-226.
Notes: Note, codes not ordered (note source: DRW codebook)

Notes: Note, codes not ordered (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Outcomes regarding Nonland Resources in War Overall
Description: Ember, C. R., & Ember, M. (1992). Warfare, aggression, and resource problems: Cross-cultural codes. Behavior Science Research, 26(1-4), 169-226.
Notes: Combined Scale Scores from Vars 1658 and 1659 According to the Rules following This Section: If both internal and external warfare were present, and if the coders made a resolved rating for both types of outcomes, we used the higher scale score of Var 1658 or 1659 for the rating of Var 1660. If there was only one resolved rating (between 1 and 5 on the original scale) and the other rating was 8 ( don't know ), we used the former, but only if that score was in the high categories (3-4); if the former scale was in the low categories (1-2), the case was listed as uncodable in Var 1660. If there was only 1 resolved rating between 1 and 5, and if the other rating was 9 ( not applicable ), we used the former for Var 1660. If the case could not be coded for the above rules, or if the original scores for internal and external warfare were 8 or 9, the case was scored as 0. (Codes Not Ordered) (note source: DRW codebook)

Name: Fact_1 News & General Gossip Scale (sum of Men, Neighbors, Socializing & News, And Women Gossip)
Description:
Gossip Factor Scales (See Divale and Seda paper with Gossip Codes for rationale). Factor analysis of Gossip variables produced eight factors with gossip variables that had loadings of .50 or higher. Scales were then produced by summing those variables with loadings of .5 or higher on the factor. Thus 1805.1 is a News & General Gossip Scale, which is the sum of the following gossip topics: Gossip about Men, Neighbors, Socializing and News, and Women). [Etc. for Factors 2-8].

Divale, W., & Seda, A. (1999). Codes on Gossip for Societies in the Standard Sanple. World Cultures, 10(1), 7-22.

Name: Fixity of settlement
Description: The community is defined as the maximal group of persons who normally reside together in face-to-face association.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Compactness of settlement
Description: This variable assesses the degree to which the local pattern of settlement is dispersed or concentrated. For societies with seasonal differences in settlement patterns, raters were instructed to specify the pattern prevailing for the longest period of the year (and to indicate the alternate pattern in parentheses).
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Size of the community population (the size of the typical community in the focal area)
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Density of community organization
Description: Assesses the nature and degree of urbanization within the indigenous society of which the focal area is a part.  Raters were instructed to ascertain which indigenous pre-European-contact settlement was largest, shared the broader culture of the focal community or area, and exercised significant effects on, or relationships with, the focal area.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Forms of the family which are predominant in the society (these family units do not necessarily co-reside)
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Forms of the family which occur often, but which do not predominate
Description: The family type in question is either the modal type, but less than 50 percent, or second in frequency to the dominant form. Not necessarily co-residential.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Dominant family household forms, or co-residential units (not necessarily under same roof) which tend to share some domestic functions, such as distribution of food, child rearing and training, preparation of meals, etc
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Dominant form of postnuptial household residence
Description: The dominant form is the one that probably more than 50 percent of the households observe. Residence can be within, or adjacent to, the house of the mother, father, male kinsman, etc., in a unilocal situation. This typology is used to classify "household units." Residence terms will also be used to classify "community settlement patterns." It is important to keep household and community separate.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Secondary form or modal form of postnuptial household residence where no form represents 50% of all practices, or where the secondary form occurs frequently, but does not dominate
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Initial temporary form of postnuptial household residence
Description: Initial form of residency can last a week, a month, a year, until the first child is born, etc. the important point is that the initial form is regarded as temporary and that a permanent form follows.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Forms of descent probably observed
Description: This is an ideological variable which stresses how individuals recognize and assign kin. This is not the same as descent groups, household residence forms, etc. Descent can be stipulated or demonstrated. Where descent is stipulated, membership in the line establishes a putative kinship bond between any two members. Where descent is demonstrated, or reckoned, claim to membership in the unit is validated by an acceptable demonstration of genealogical connection with another member of the line; the "demonstration" need not coincide with the actual genealogical tree.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.
Notes: NOTE:  Case 1 had a value of 5. This was changed to missing data. [World Cultures 10(2), fall 1999]

Name: Forms of kinship units
Description: Kinship units can be described by reference to marriage, descent, and residence. They can also be described by reference to location, internal relationships, activities, ownership of property, and relationships between units. Variables follow which control for all of these properties. Descent units are demonstrated, and are unilineal or nonunilineal.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Political organization and the allocation of access to important means for producing sustenance
Description: This variable refers to intragroup area resources e.g., land for farming, water for irrigation, hunting, fishing, gathering rights etc., and whether or not these resources are allocated internally among families or kin groups by some political authority above kin group headmen. This does not include the question of whether or not village boundaries are maintained and resources are "jealously guarded against poaching by outsiders."
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Political organization and the allocation of civic duties such as labor or military conscription
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.
Changes: Political org and punishment of crimes

Name: Nature of tribal sodalities
Description: A sodality is a subdivision of a society whose members are not primarily determined by kinship or by co-residence. Membership in these groups of "associates," "friends," "comrades," etc., is generally voluntary and not ascribed at birth, though older relations may exert pressures to persuade a person to join the sodality that they consider to be the proper one. The tribal sodality is the most encompassing type, and it entails some procedure of initiation and education either in tribal lore, religious secrets, or both.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Restricted sodalities
Description: The term "restricted sodality" applies to an organization with membership restricted to only a part of the mature males, or the mature females, or a mixture of both short of the totality, Restricted sodalities may also have initiation ceremonies, as well as other rituals, with content and meaning unknown to the nonmembers in the remainder of the population.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Sex-dominance of restricted sodalities
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Functions of restricted sodalities
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Restricted sodality: Participants and spectators
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Objects of restricted sodality functions
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Clubs and age-classes
Description: Clubs and age-classes are informal sodalities without any secrets. Age-classes are special types of sodalities that include any division of a population into organized age-groups of a more or less permanent nature.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Club and age-class membership
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Duels between members of the same society
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.
Changes: Duels between members of same society

Name: Feuds within the local community or extralocal organization
Description: Feuds refer to conflicts between two families, lineages, clans, sibs, demes, or other kinship groups. They are often protracted series of reprisals that are not settled, mainly because there is no mechanism to settle them
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.
Changes: Feuds within or btwn local communities

Name: Raids motivated by desire for economic booty such as hides, pottery, food, etc
Description: Raids are single, small military engagements of short duration. They are motivated by desire for booty, women, slaves, prestige, vengeance or a slain warrior, or to fulfill a vision or instructions received through dreams. A raiding party has a leader and from as few as five to as many as 50 people.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.
Notes: NOTE: Case 64 had a value of 4. This was changed to missing data. [World Cultures 10(2), fall 1999]

Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Incidence of raiding
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Incidence of defense against raiding
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Presence of buffer zones
Description: A buffer zone is defined as "no man?ÇÖs land" between subsistence areas owned by different groups. If members of either group enter the buffer zone to hunt, fish, farm, or gather, it is possible that they could suffer an attack from the opposing group, and both groups recognize the danger of entering the buffer zones, even if they did so frequently.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Incidence of warfare
Description: Warfare is defined as conflicts between two factions with true political organization, each of which possesses definite leadership, some kind of military tactics, and at least the hope of being able to weather a series of battles.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Motives for engaging in warfare
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Permanent military organizations
Description: These are defined as restricted sodalities or armies, conscripted or freely joined, with definite leadership.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Special fighting regalia
Description: These are defined as special weapons, armament, dress, or insignias.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Public ceremonies associated with warfare or raids
Description: These ceremonies can be performed before or after a conflict, but are performed in public and not merely for the participants.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Major public ceremonies performed for people other than members of religious sodalities and the like
Description: A "major" ceremony draws all or most of the sponsoring group together for its performance, and is considered major in importance by the participants.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Attendance at largest public ceremony
Description: The "largest" public ceremony would be the one having the largest attendance, the most splendid event in the cultural repertoire, the one having the greatest number of ancillary activities, or a ceremony having some combination of these three attributes.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Dominant sacred or profane nature of major public ceremonies
Description: The variable assesses whether major public ceremonies are by nature more sacred (dealing with supernatural acts and beliefs for supernatural ends), more profane (dealing with more mundane, less supernatural acts and ideology), or whether they are accompanied by both types of acts and ideology and there is no clear evidence to show that one dominates the other.
Source: Data imported from WNAI text files wn01.dat - wn08.dat, included in folder 10#2 of World Cultures CD-ROM (2011). Codes from Jorgensen, J. G. (1999) Codebook for Western Indians Data. 1999 World Cultures 10(2): 144-293.

Name: Variance in net primary production per month
Description: Variance in net primary production per month

Name: Net primary production per month (grams of carbon uptake per square meter of land per month)
Description: Net primary production per month (grams of carbon uptake per square meter of land per month)

Name: Net primary production constancy
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable because conditions are constant. Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Net primary production contingency
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable because conditions oscillate in a very predictable manner.  Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Net primary production predictability
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable due to either constancy or contingency.  Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Biome
Description: Classification by Olson et al. (2001) of the earth into fourteen units that host similar formations of plants and animals due to their climates. A single biome can be found over a range of continents.

Name: EcoRegion
Description: Classification by Olson et al. (2001) of the earth into zones (ecoregions) encompassing distinct biotas. Ecoregions are nested within Biomes.

Name: Number of coexisting vascular plant species.
Description: Number of coexisting vascular plant species.

Name: Number of coexisting amphibian species
Description: Number of coexisting amphibian species.

Name: Number of coexisting bird species
Description: Number of coexisting bird species.

Name: Number of coexisting mammal species
Description: Number of coexisting mammal species.

Name: Distance to coast
Description: Distance to coast

Name: Precipitation constancy
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable because conditions are constant. Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Precipitation contingency
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable because conditions oscillate in a very predictable manner.  Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Precipitation predictability
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable due to either constancy or contingency.  Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Temperature constancy
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable because conditions are constant. Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Temperature contingency
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which climate patterns are predictable because conditions oscillate in a very predictable manner.  Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).

Name: Temperature predictability
Description: Colwell's (1974) information theoretic index. Indicates the extent to which a climate patterns are predictable due to either constancy or contingency.  Varies between 0 (completely unpredictable) and 1 (fully predictable).
